NET_UUID = '3faeebfe-5d37-11e1-a64b-000c29d5f0a7' VLAN = 42 SEG_ID = str(VLAN) VIF_ID = '404deaec-5d37-11e1-a64b-000c29d5f0a8' VIF_MAC = '3c:09:24:1e:78:23' PHYS_NET = 'physnet' OFPORT_NUM = 1 VIF_PORT = ovs_lib.VifPort('port', OFPORT_NUM, VIF_ID, VIF_MAC, 'switch') VIF_PORTS = {VLAN: VIF_PORT} LVM = ovs_neutron_agent.LocalVLANMapping(VLAN, 'vlan', PHYS_NET, SEG_ID, VIF_PORTS) # # class FakeThing(object): # """An object to pass in that will return itself under most circumstances. # # This is useful if you want to basically turn any call or method into a # NOOP. # # >>> f = FakeThing() # >>> f # <fake.FakeThing object at 0x7f26553602d0> # >>> f() # <fake.FakeThing object at 0x7f26553602d0> # >>> f.foo.bar() # <fake.FakeThing object at 0x7f26553602d0> # >>> f.foo['bar'].baz() # <fake.FakeThing object at 0x7f26553602d0> # # """ # # def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): # pass # # def __getattribute__(self, name): # return self # # def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): # return self # # def __getitem__(self, name): # return self class VLANTest(unittest.TestCase): def setUp(self): self.INT_BRIDGE = 'integration_bridge' self.PHY_BRIDGE = 'physical_bridge' self.VETH_MTU = None ip_lib.device_exists = Mock() #br_name, root_helper patcher_ovsbridge = patch('neutron.agent.linux.ovs_lib.OVSBridge') patcher_phybridge = patch('neutron.agent.linux.ovs_lib.OVSBridge') patcher_ipwrapper = patch('neutron.agent.linux.ip_lib.IPWrapper') MockIntOVSBridge = patcher_ovsbridge.start() MockPhyOVSBridge = patcher_phybridge.start() MockIPWrapper = patcher_ipwrapper.start() self.mock_int_bridge = MockIntOVSBridge(self.INT_BRIDGE, 'sudo') ip_wrapper = MockIPWrapper('sudo') # From OVSNeutrongent.setup_integration_br self.mock_int_bridge.delete_port('patch-tun') self.mock_int_bridge.remove_all_flows() self.mock_int_bridge.add_flow(priority=1, actions='normal') ip_lib.device_exists(self.PHY_BRIDGE, 'sudo').AndReturn(True) self.mock_phy_bridge = MockPhyOVSBridge(self.PHY_BRIDGE, 'sudo') self.mock_phy_bridge.remove_all_flows() self.mock_phy_bridge.add_flow(priority=1, actions='normal') int_veth_name = "int-%s" % (self.PHY_BRIDGE,) phy_veth_name = "phy-%s" % (self.PHY_BRIDGE,) self.mock_int_bridge.delete_port(int_veth_name) self.mock_phy_bridge.delete_port(phy_veth_name) ip_lib.device_exists(int_veth_name, 'sudo').AndReturn(False) int_veth = ip_lib.IPDevice(int_veth_name) phy_veth = ip_lib.IPDevice(phy_veth_name) ip_lib.IpLinkCommand.delete = Mock() ip_wrapper.add_veth(int_veth_name, phy_veth_name).AndReturn((int_veth, phy_veth)) # Stub out the IpLinkCommands with something that will do nothing int_veth.link = phy_veth.link = Mock() self.int_ofport = self.mock_int_bridge.add_port(int_veth).AndReturn(3) self.phy_ofport = self.mock_phy_bridge.add_port(phy_veth).AndReturn(4) self.mock_int_bridge.add_flow(priority=2, in_port=self.int_ofport, actions='drop') self.mock_phy_bridge.add_flow(priority=2, in_port=self.phy_ofport, actions='drop') self.mock_int_bridge.get_local_port_mac = \ Mock(return_value='000000000001') self.mock_phy_bridge.get_local_port_mac = \ Mock(return_value='000000000002') self.mock_int_bridge.add_flow = Mock() self.mock_phy_bridge.add_flow = Mock() self.mock_int_bridge.rec ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.setup_rpc = Mock() ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.setup_physical_bridges = Mock() ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.setup_ancillary_bridges = Mock() ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.phys_brs = Mock() ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.phys_brs.__iter__ =\ Mock(return_value=iter([])) ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.int_ofports = Mock() ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.context = \ Mock("context") ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.topic = \ Mock("topic") ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.plugin_rpc = \ Mock("plugin_rpc") ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent.state_rpc = \ Mock("state_rpc") def testConstruct(self): ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent(self.INT_BRIDGE, None, '10.0.0.1', {PHYS_NET: self.PHY_BRIDGE}, 'sudo', 2, None, self.VETH_MTU) self.assertEqual(self.mock_int_bridge.get_local_port_mac(), '000000000001') self.assertEqual(self.mock_phy_bridge.get_local_port_mac(), '000000000002') def testProvisionLocalVlan(self): action_string = 'mod_vlan_vid:%s,normal' % (SEG_ID,) self.mock_phy_bridge.add_flow(priority=4, in_port=self.phy_ofport, dl_vlan=VLAN, actions=action_string) action_string = 'mod_vlan_vid:%s,normal' % (VLAN,) self.mock_int_bridge.add_flow(priority=3, in_port=self.int_ofport, dl_vlan=SEG_ID, actions=action_string) a = ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent(self.INT_BRIDGE, None, '10.0.0.1', {PHYS_NET: self.PHY_BRIDGE}, 'sudo', 2, None, self.VETH_MTU) a.available_local_vlans = set([VLAN]) a.provision_local_vlan(NET_UUID, 'vlan', PHYS_NET, SEG_ID) def testReclaimLocalVlan(self): self.mock_phy_bridge.delete_flows(in_port=self.phy_ofport, dl_vlan=VLAN) self.mock_int_bridge.delete_flows(in_port=self.int_ofport, dl_vlan=SEG_ID) a = ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent(self.INT_BRIDGE, None, '10.0.0.1', {PHYS_NET: self.PHY_BRIDGE}, 'sudo', 2, False) self.mock_int_bridge.get_local_port_mac() self.mock_phy_bridge.get_local_port_mac() a.available_local_vlans = set() a.local_vlan_map[NET_UUID] = LVM a.provision_local_vlan(NET_UUID, 'vlan', PHYS_NET, SEG_ID) a.reclaim_local_vlan(NET_UUID, LVM) self.assertTrue(LVM.vlan in a.available_local_vlans) def testPortBound(self): self.mock_int_bridge.set_db_attribute('Port', VIF_PORT.port_name, 'tag', str(LVM.vlan)) self.mock_int_bridge.delete_flows(in_port=VIF_PORT.ofport) a = ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent(self.INT_BRIDGE, None, '10.0.0.1', {PHYS_NET: self.PHY_BRIDGE}, 'sudo', 2, False) a.local_vlan_map[NET_UUID] = LVM a.port_bound(VIF_PORT, NET_UUID, 'vlan', PHYS_NET, SEG_ID) self.assertEquals(LVM.vif_ports[VIF_PORT.vif_id], VIF_PORT) def testPortUnbound(self): a = ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent(self.INT_BRIDGE, None, '10.0.0.1', {PHYS_NET: self.PHY_BRIDGE}, 'sudo', 2, False) a.available_local_vlans = set([VLAN]) a.local_vlan_map[NET_UUID] = LVM a.port_unbound(VIF_ID, NET_UUID) self.assertFalse(LVM.vif_ports.pop(VIF_ID, None)) def testPortDead(self): self.mock_int_bridge.set_db_attribute( 'Port', VIF_PORT.port_name, 'tag', ovs_neutron_agent.DEAD_VLAN_TAG) self.mock_int_bridge.add_flow(priority=2, in_port=VIF_PORT.ofport, actions='drop') a = ovs_neutron_agent.OVSNeutronAgent(self.INT_BRIDGE, None, '10.0.0.1', {PHYS_NET: self.PHY_BRIDGE}, 'sudo', 2, False) a.available_local_vlans = set([VLAN]) a.local_vlan_map[NET_UUID] = LVM a.port_dead(VIF_PORT) self.mock_int_bridge.add_flow.assert_called_with(priority=2, in_port= VIF_PORT.ofport, actions="drop")

commit_message:
Added native ipmi driver

Implemented a power driver for baremetal node that uses the a native
python ipmi driver called pyghmi. Due to the name conflict, ipmi.py
has been changed to ipmitool.py.

Implements: blueprint native-ipmi
Change-Id: I2b9f32876ba01d9d08ba1fc34d5340b14da7c997

commit_message:
Call the set_hostname method on Agent during spawn

Call set_hostname method on Agent if agent supports
this feature. This is required for PV tools 6.1 where
rename feature has been removed.

Fixes: bug #1182934
Change-Id: I8563ecc656f1c5819688f550845f263dd8a93bf9

commit_message:
Move comment back to right place

The comment about skipping schedule for create volume from snapshot
in cast_create_volume() was mis-placed when this code was ported to
taskflow.  This patch moves the comment back to where it belongs.

Change-Id: I329c78a05143bf8589d9665dc4ff03fa80da6ec9

commit_message:
Improve support for RHEL derivatives

CentOS, Scientific, SLC, OracleLinux, Amazon, etc. should be treated
just like RedHat.

commit_message:
Use testtools as base test class.

Minor tests refactoring due to use testtools:
 - added missed setUp() and tearDown() to call these functions in
   base test case.
 - removed some superfluous tearDown() calls.
 - moved test_crud_inherited_role_grants_failed_if_disabled() method
   to separate class.

Fixes for python 2.6 enviroment:
 - replaced `with self.assertRaises(Exception): foo()` to
   `self.assertRaises(Exception, foo)
 - added to safe_repr(), assertDictEqual() and assertRaisesRegexp() methods
   to TestCase() class in keystone/test.py

Fixes bug 1179009

Change-Id: Iea67ad10d02db82fc8ed79b1096ddb5233925bfd

commit_message:
Clarify sql string when not using nova-conductor

You do not have to use nova-conductor and can
instead use direct DB connections from the compute
nodes. This change makes a note and clarifies the
nova.conf changes which are required if you wish to
do so.

Change-Id: I60baf1b235172ef4ea8152b0119543d17e07cd42

commit_message:
Add support for FC zone lifecycle management

Allows automated zone lifecycle management in the attach/detach
entry points of the volume manager for FC volumes (when fabric
zoning is enabled). Zones are configured automatically as part
of the active zone set in the FC SAN to provide a more flexible
and secure way of controlling access. FC zone manager enables
SAN vendors to add support for pluggable implementations.

TODO: Base PWWN lookup support, common code refactoring, SSH
connection pool review comments, exception/error handling
review comments

Change-Id: I0a9ef5b8e785c53fe4b35cf997f45feb89840c8c
Implements: blueprint cinder-fc-zone-manager
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/72/41772/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # (c) Copyright 2013 Brocade Communication Systems Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Copyright 2013 OpenStack LLC # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # """ ZoneManager is responsible to manage access control using FC zoning when zoning mode is set as 'fabric'. ZoneManager provides interfaces to add connection and remove connection for given initiator and target list associated with a FC volume attach and detach operation. **Related Flags** :zone_driver: Used by :class:`ZoneManager`. Defaults to `cinder.volume.drivers.san.brocade.brcd_fczonedriver.BrcdFCZoneDriver`. :zoning_policy: Used by: class: 'ZoneManager'. Defaults to 'none' """ import sys import traceback from oslo.config import cfg from cinder import context from cinder import exception from cinder import flags from cinder import manager from cinder.openstack.common import excutils from cinder.openstack.common import importutils from cinder.openstack.common import lockutils from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder.openstack.common import timeutils from cinder.volume.configuration import Configuration LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) zone_manager_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('zone_driver', default='cinder.volume.drivers.san.brocade.brcd_fc_zone_driver.BrcdFCZoneDriver', help='FC Zone Driver responsible for zone management'), cfg.StrOpt('zoning_policy', default='initiator-target', help='Zoning policy configured by user'), ] FLAGS = flags.FLAGS FLAGS.register_opts(zone_manager_opts) """ Class to provide automated zone management functionality. This class provides APIs to add connection control and remove connection control during FC volume attach/detach operations. """ class ZoneManager: """Manages Connection control during attach/detach""" driver = None driver_type = 'None' fabric_names = [] def __init__(self, zone_driver=None, service_name=None, **kwargs): driver_type = kwargs['driver_volume_type'] """Load the driver from the one specified in args, or from flags.""" self.configuration = kwargs.get('configuration', None) if self.configuration: self.configuration.append_config_values(zone_manager_opts) zone_driver = self.configuration.zone_driver LOG.debug(_("Zone Driver from config: {%s}"), zone_driver) # Initialize vendor specific implementation of FCZoneDriver self.driver = importutils.import_object( zone_driver, configuration=self.configuration) """ Performs state check for given I-T pair to return the current count of active attach for the pair. """ def get_zoning_state_ref_count(self, initiator_wwn, target_wwn): LOG.info(_("check ref count called")) count = 0 # check the state for I-T pair return count def _log_original_error(self, exc_info): type_, value, tb = exc_info LOG.error(_('Error: %s') % traceback.format_exception(type_, value, tb)) """ Adds connection control for the given initiator target map. initiator_target_map - each initiator WWN mapped to a list of one or more target WWN: eg: { '10008c7cff523b01' : ['20240002ac000a50', '20240002ac000a40'] } """ def add_connection(self, context, initiator_target_map): """Call Driver to add or update zones""" context = context.elevated() try: for initiator in initiator_target_map.keys(): target_list = initiator_target_map[initiator] LOG.debug(_("Target List for initiator:{%s} is {%s}"), initiator, target_list) # get SAN context for the target list fabric_map = self.get_san_context(target_list) LOG.info(_("Fabric Map after context lookup:%s"), fabric_map) # iterate over each SAN and apply connection control for fabric in fabric_map.keys(): t_list = fabric_map[fabric] LOG.debug(_("Fabric %s, targets: %s"), fabric, t_list) # get valid I-T map to add connection control i_t_map = { initiator : t_list } valid_i_t_map = self.get_valid_initiator_target_map(i_t_map, 'true') LOG.debug(_("Final filtered map for fabric: %s is: %s"), fabric, valid_i_t_map) # Call driver to add connection control self.driver.add_connection(fabric, valid_i_t_map) LOG.info(_("Finished iterating over all target list")) except Exception as e: LOG.info(_("Failed adding connection, {%s}"), e) raise LOG.info(_("Added access control successfully")) pass """ Adds connection control for the given initiator target map. initiator_target_map - each initiator WWN mapped to a list of one or more target WWN: eg: { '10008c7cff523b01' : ['20240002ac000a50', '20240002ac000a40'] } """ def delete_connection(self, context, initiator_target_map): try: for initiator in initiator_target_map.keys(): target_list = initiator_target_map[initiator] LOG.info(_("Delete connection - Target List for initiator:{%s} is {%s}"), initiator, target_list) # get SAN context for the target list fabric_map = self.get_san_context(target_list) LOG.debug(_("Fabric Map:%s"), fabric_map) # iterate over each SAN and apply connection control for fabric in fabric_map.keys(): t_list = fabric_map[fabric] LOG.debug(_("Fabric %s, targets: %s"), fabric, t_list) # get valid I-T map to add connection control i_t_map = { initiator : t_list } valid_i_t_map = self.get_valid_initiator_target_map(i_t_map, 'false') LOG.info(_("Final filtered map for delete connection : %s"), valid_i_t_map) # Call driver to delete connection control if valid_i_t_map.__len__() > 0 : self.driver.delete_connection(fabric, valid_i_t_map) LOG.debug(_("Delete Connection - Finished iterating over all target list")) except Exception as e: LOG.info(_("Failed Removing connection, {%s}"), e) raise LOG.debug(_("Updated/deleted access control successfully")) pass """ Look up each SAN configured and return a map of SAN (fabric IP) to list of target WWNs visible to the fabric. """ def get_san_context(self, target_wwn_list): fabric_map = self.driver.get_san_context(target_wwn_list) return fabric_map """ Looks up the reference count for each initiator-target pair from the map and returns a filtered list based on the operation type add_control - operation type can be true for add connection control and false for remove connection control """ def get_valid_initiator_target_map(self, initiator_target_map, add_control): filtered_i_t_map = {} for initiator in initiator_target_map.keys(): t_list = initiator_target_map[initiator] for target in t_list: count = self.get_zoning_state_ref_count(initiator, target) if (add_control == 'true') : if (count > 0) : t_list.remove(target) # update count = count + 1 else : if (count > 1) : t_list.remove(target) # update count = count - 1 if (len(t_list) > 0) : filtered_i_t_map[initiator] = t_list else : LOG.info(_("No targets to add or remove connection for I : %s, T-List: %s"), initiator, initiator_target_map[initiator]) return filtered_i_t_map

commit_message:
Remove testcase test_invalid_auth_version_request

In keystoneclient/middleware/auth_token.py, _choose_api_version(), the
codes's logic assume that auth_version in conf is always correct, so the
testcase test_invalid_auth_version_request() is incorrect. This patch
remove it.

Fixes bug #1218881

Change-Id: I6aec0526a6a60eea8d357ec1b44570e7d74da653
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/48/44448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove keep_data_fp argument from DiskFile constructor

All access to the data_file fp for DiskFile is moved under the new "open"
method.  This reduces the surface area of the DiskFile abstraction and reduces
the exposure of the underlying implementation in the object-server.

Future work:

 * Add public "create" method to DiskFile to wrap DiskWriter
 * Add public "delete" method to DiskFile
 * Consolidate put_metadata to DiskWriter
 * Add public "update_metdata" method to DiskFile
 * Move all access of .metadata property in object-server under "open"
 * Create DiskReader class to gather all access of methods under "open"

Change-Id: I932ab3669e4cd1a48555cdadbeb984ba6c8efb1a

commit_message:
Make obj-auditor audit to data w/ multiple store policies

object will be stored in directories like 'objects', 'objects-1',
'objects-2'..., so simply update obj-auditor to audit these data
also.

Change-Id: I76dbc6c33a0c9093df4bf7cf00b0f2747ebd978d

subject: Create RPC connection before modifying OVS bridges
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-29 07:36:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/615b0623375594ddcfd7e63887f2224186650a71', 'message': 'Create RPC connection before modifying OVS bridges

On startup, the agent removes and readds flows to the OVS bridges.  If
an RPC setup error exits the process prematurely, this can leave the
bridges in an unsafe state.  It is better to set the RPC communication
up before making changes to the host system.

Closes-Bug: 1217980
Change-Id: Ib9bbb864b9129bb7b1376a150a37a0c07908d74b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Gran <stephen.gran@guardian.co.uk>

commit_message:
Create RPC connection before modifying OVS bridges

On startup, the agent removes and readds flows to the OVS bridges.  If
an RPC setup error exits the process prematurely, this can leave the
bridges in an unsafe state.  It is better to set the RPC communication
up before making changes to the host system.

Closes-Bug: 1217980
Change-Id: Ib9bbb864b9129bb7b1376a150a37a0c07908d74b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Gran <stephen.gran@guardian.co.uk>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/29/44229/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.int_br = self.get_integration_br(integ_br) self.setup_rpc() self.setup_integration_br() def get_integration_br(self, bridge_name): '''Retrieve the name of the integration bridge. :param bridge_name: the name of the integration bridge. :returns: the integration bridge ''' return ovs_lib.OVSBridge(bridge_name, self.root_helper) def setup_integration_br(self): self.int_br.delete_port(cfg.CONF.OVS.int_peer_patch_port) self.int_br.remove_all_flows() self.int_br.add_flow(priority=1, actions="normal")
deleted_lines: self.int_br = self.setup_integration_br(integ_br) self.setup_rpc() def setup_integration_br(self, bridge_name): int_br = ovs_lib.OVSBridge(bridge_name, self.root_helper) int_br.delete_port(cfg.CONF.OVS.int_peer_patch_port) int_br.remove_all_flows() int_br.add_flow(priority=1, actions="normal") return int_br

commit_message:
Implement decorator-based notifications for users

Refactors the keystone.notifications module to use decorators, and
applies those new decorators to user CRUD operations at the manager
layer.

blueprint notifications

Change-Id: Ic7937657196a0ad19923153a5135b1451a533e81

added_lines: from keystone import notifications notifications.send_update(context, None, tenant_ref, 'identity') notifications.send_update(context, tenant, tenant_ref, 'identity') notifications.send_update(context, tenant_id, None, 'identity')

Resouce tracker of compute node use PCI tracker's interface
to test resouce, claim the PCI devices, alloc and free the
instance's PCI devices.

commit_message:
Add PCI device tracker to compute resource tracker

PCI device tracker manages all the PCI devices life cycle.

The resource tracker on a compute node uses the PCI device tracker's
interface to query for resources, claim PCI devices, and alloc and
free PCI devices for instances.

bp:pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I766d7f92e26fb75c1d6095dc0237c44f938d4170
Signed-off-by: Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Yunhong Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Adds Instance UUID to rsync debug logging

This commit adds the instance uuid to the rsync debug output in
the debug logs. The issue we were seeing is that when multiple
migrations are ongoing at the same time, it's not easy to
track the rsync progress of each migration.
Fixes: bug #1215629

Change-Id: Iec662bdc0aed1c6f54ecaa062335dc5504ac030f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/00/43200/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: logging.debug(rsync_progress)

commit_message:
Allow users to extract tars to containers with ACLs set

This fixes bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1203182 (well
it should :) I don't have keystone installed but the same issue
existed with tempauth).

Change-Id: I6f4045f484b27c0153a9244e0dbf2641cbc9e84e

subject: Avoid swallowing exceptions in network manager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-25 10:19:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5682b44184f1bff54e42dd21974351f57b7846ee', 'message': "Avoid swallowing exceptions in _allocate_fixed_ips()

In _allocate_fixed_ips(), we spawn off green threads to call
_rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() on remote network managers, but if there is an
exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

Change-Id: I7af1c4c1869edf3601809fe02fb82b12c8b70811
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-08-25 10:34:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/203b72a5cc467c2cacad927d0d02bf116b88f2e9', 'message': "Avoid swallowing exceptions in network manager

In _allocate_fixed_ips() and setup_networks_on_host(), we spawn off
green threads to call _rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() and
rpc_setup_network_on_host() on remote network managers, but if there is
an exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

Change-Id: I7af1c4c1869edf3601809fe02fb82b12c8b70811
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-08-27 21:58:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6db3b04e176e47dacff6e8635655b3993c1978cd', 'message': "Avoid swallowing exceptions in network manager

In _allocate_fixed_ips() and setup_networks_on_host(), we spawn off
green threads to call _rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() and
rpc_setup_network_on_host() on remote network managers, but if there is
an exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

blueprint: oslo-messaging
Change-Id: I7af1c4c1869edf3601809fe02fb82b12c8b70811
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2013-08-27 23:11:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/63ee037919c5fbebfb66346fccb8798935a5b52d', 'message': "Avoid swallowing exceptions in network manager

In _allocate_fixed_ips() and setup_networks_on_host(), we spawn off
green threads to call _rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() and
rpc_setup_network_on_host() on remote network managers, but if there is
an exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

blueprint: oslo-messaging
Change-Id: I7af1c4c1869edf3601809fe02fb82b12c8b70811
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2013-08-29 08:48:18.000000000', 'files': ['nova/network/manager.py', 'nova/tests/integrated/v3/api_sample_base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/141a1eb8052ea65d01e3c2981f265116cdd6e4bb', 'message': "Avoid swallowing exceptions in network manager

In _allocate_fixed_ips() and setup_networks_on_host(), we spawn off
green threads to call _rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() and
rpc_setup_network_on_host() on remote network managers, but if there is
an exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

commit_message:
Avoid swallowing exceptions in network manager

In _allocate_fixed_ips() and setup_networks_on_host(), we spawn off
green threads to call _rpc_allocate_fixed_ip() and
rpc_setup_network_on_host() on remote network managers, but if there is
an exception in the thread it just gets swallowed.

We don't really need a GreenPool here. It's not like its limit of 1000
threads is relevant here. Just use eventlet.spawn(), collect the list of
threads spawned and call wait() on each of them. This will ensure the
exception gets raised by wait().

Also, fix a case in the v3 integrated servers test where we are setting
up fake networks which are associated with a non-existent 'fake-mini'
host. See also I9854863bbec8834c638c55832411f63da570f82d.

blueprint: oslo-messaging
Change-Id: I7af1c4c1869edf3601809fe02fb82b12c8b70811

These both apply to the proxy servers:

First, instead of consturction a dict just to use with `.update()` simply set a
set of keys in the headers dict.

Second, generating the headers for proxy requests once, no matter how many

Change-Id: Ib42bf7750e175a6ad9b777fa35655380feeafb93

commit_message:
Two small performance improvements to header generation

These both apply to the proxy servers:

First, instead of consturction a dict just to use with `.update()` simply set a
set of keys in the headers dict.

Second, generating the headers for proxy requests once, no matter how many
backend servers are accessed (instead of once per backend server), they all get
the same headers.

Change-Id: Ib42bf7750e175a6ad9b777fa35655380feeafb93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/45/44545/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: headers['x-trans-id'] = self.trans_id headers['connection'] = 'close' headers['user-agent'] = 'proxy-server %s' % os.getpid() headers['referer'] = referer headers = self.generate_request_headers(req, additional=req.headers)
deleted_lines: headers.update({'x-trans-id': self.trans_id, 'connection': 'close', 'user-agent': 'proxy-server %s' % os.getpid(), 'referer': referer}) headers = self.generate_request_headers( req, additional=req.headers)

commit_message:
Add support for Docker as Nova hypervisor

* Add basic support for hypervisor plugins in lib/nova_plugins
* Add lib/nova_plugins/hypervisor-docker to use Docker as a Nova
  hypervisor.
* Add tools/install_docker.sh to install the Docker daemon and
  registry container, download base image and import
* Configure Nova to use docker plugin
* Add docker exercise and skip unsupported ones

Nova blueprint: new-hypervisor-docker

Change-Id: I9e7065b562dce2ce853def583ab1165886612227

deleted_lines: if [ "$VIRT_DRIVER" = 'xenserver' ]; then

commit_message:
Standardize base.py with novaclient

Main changes:
* deprecate api variable in favour of client
* add documentation
* use to_slug from oslo strutils
* remove Python 2.4 support
* other small fixes from novaclient

Change-Id: Ife54fd3207798ee03101a48bc1cda3b3f62cc5e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/09/42909/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2011 OpenStack LLC # Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation# E1102: %s is not callable # pylint: disable=E1102 from keystoneclient.openstack.common import strutils def getid(obj): """Return id if argument is a Resource. Abstracts the common pattern of allowing both an object or an object's ID (UUID) as a parameter when dealing with relationships. """ """Basic manager type providing common operations. Managers interact with a particular type of API (servers, flavors, images, etc.) and provide CRUD operations for them. def __init__(self, client): """Initializes Manager with `client`. :param client: instance of BaseClient descendant for HTTP requests """ super(Manager, self).__init__() self.client = client @property def api(self): """Deprecated. Use `client` instead. """ return self.client """List the collection. :param url: a partial URL, e.g., '/servers' :param response_key: the key to be looked up in response dictionary, e.g., 'servers' :param obj_class: class for constructing the returned objects (self.resource_class will be used by default) :param body: data that will be encoded as JSON and passed in POST request (GET will be sent by default) """ if body: resp, body = self.client.post(url, body=body) else: resp, body = self.client.get(url) try: except (KeyError, TypeError): pass """Get an object from collection. :param url: a partial URL, e.g., '/servers' :param response_key: the key to be looked up in response dictionary, e.g., 'server' """ _, body = self.client.get(url) """Retrieve request headers for an object. :param url: a partial URL, e.g., '/servers' """ resp, _ = self.client.head(url) """Deprecated. Use `_post` instead. """ return self._post(url, body, response_key, return_raw) def _post(self, url, body, response_key, return_raw=False): """Create an object. :param url: a partial URL, e.g., '/servers' :param body: data that will be encoded as JSON and passed in POST request (GET will be sent by default) :param response_key: the key to be looked up in response dictionary, e.g., 'servers' :param return_raw: flag to force returning raw JSON instead of Python object of self.resource_class """ _, body = self.client.post(url, body=body) def _put(self, url, body=None, response_key=None): """Update an object with PUT method. :param url: a partial URL, e.g., '/servers' :param body: data that will be encoded as JSON and passed in POST request (GET will be sent by default) :param response_key: the key to be looked up in response dictionary, e.g., 'servers' """ resp, body = self.client.put(url, body=body) # PUT requests may not return a body if resp.content: if response_key is not None: return self.resource_class(self, body[response_key]) else: return self.resource_class(self, body) def _patch(self, url, body=None, response_key=None): """Update an object with PATCH method. :param url: a partial URL, e.g., '/servers' :param body: data that will be encoded as JSON and passed in POST request (GET will be sent by default) :param response_key: the key to be looked up in response dictionary, e.g., 'servers' """ _, body = self.client.patch(url, body=body) if response_key is not None: return self.resource_class(self, body[response_key]) else: return self.resource_class(self, body) def _delete(self, url): """Delete an object. :param url: a partial URL, e.g., '/servers/my-server' """ return self.client.delete(url) """Manager with additional `find()`/`findall()` methods.""" num = len(rl) raise exceptions.NotFound(msg) elif num > 1: raise exceptions.NoUniqueMatch() """ Find a single item with attributes matching ``**kwargs``. """ raise exceptions.NotFound(msg) elif num > 1: raise exceptions.NoUniqueMatch() """Base class for OpenStack resources (tenant, user, etc.). This is pretty much just a bag for attributes. HUMAN_ID = False NAME_ATTR = 'name' def __init__(self, manager, info, loaded=False): """Populate and bind to a manager. :param manager: Manager object :param info: dictionary representing resource attributes :param loaded: prevent lazy-loading if set to True """ @property def human_id(self): """Human-readable ID which can be used for bash completion. """ if self.NAME_ATTR in self.__dict__ and self.HUMAN_ID: return strutils.to_slug(getattr(self, self.NAME_ATTR)) return None try: setattr(self, k, v) self._info[k] = v except AttributeError: # In this case we already defined the attribute on the class pass if not isinstance(other, Resource): return NotImplemented # two resources of different types are not equal
deleted_lines: # Copyright 2011 OpenStack LLC.# Python 2.4 compat try: all except NameError: def all(iterable): return True not in (not x for x in iterable) def getid(obj): """Abstracts the common pattern of allowing both an object or an object's ID (UUID) as a parameter when dealing with relationships. """ # Try to return the object's UUID first, if we have a UUID. """Managers interact with a particular type of API (servers, flavors, images, etc.) and provide CRUD operations for them. def __init__(self, api): self.api = api resp = None if body: resp, body = self.api.post(url, body=body) else: resp, body = self.api.get(url) if type(data) is dict: resp, body = self.api.get(url) resp, body = self.api.head(url) resp, body = self.api.post(url, body=body) def _delete(self, url): resp, body = self.api.delete(url) """Like a `Manager`, but with additional `find()`/`findall()` methods. """ num = len(rl) raise exceptions.NotFound(404, msg) elif num > 1: raise exceptions.NoUniqueMatch """Find a single item with attributes matching ``**kwargs``.""" raise exceptions.NotFound(404, msg) elif num > 1: raise exceptions.NoUniqueMatch """A resource represents a particular instance of an object (tenant, user, etc). This is pretty much just a bag for attributes. :param manager: Manager object :param info: dictionary representing resource attributes :param loaded: prevent lazy-loading if set to True def __init__(self, manager, info, loaded=False): setattr(self, k, v)

commit_message:
Fixing potential NameErrors

Fixing a couple locations that could potentially raise NameErrors
instead of intended exceptions.  These were found by looking at
flake8 F821 (undefined name) errors.

Added in unit tests to verify NameErrors would not be raised.

Change-Id: I8619cb0be495b814335a5aea23daca025484d3c6

commit_message:
Allow admins to update default quotas

Add update default quotas form to edit the default quotas.

Move the editable default quotas tab to a new panel called
"Defaults".

Implements blueprint edit-default-quota

Change-Id: I6e3806226cd2f699f16b93c25e294bc67883738f

The new apiclient.exceptions hierarchy is more comprehensive
and it covers almost all HTTP error status codes. These
exceptions can be used in novaclient, keystoneclient,
glanceclient, and other client projects thus providing a
single inteface.

Users can have benefit from OpenStack clients raising exceptions
of known classes while now every client has its own classes making
difficult to catch, e.g., NotFound for every client.

Change-Id: Ia7b25880e0ffca3526525a0f0e77c7e77c4f0076

exceptions can be used in novaclient, keystoneclient,
glanceclient, and other client projects thus providing a
single inteface.

Users can have benefit from OpenStack clients raising exceptions
of known classes while now every client has its own classes making
difficult to catch, e.g., NotFound for every client.

Change-Id: Ia7b25880e0ffca3526525a0f0e77c7e77c4f0076
'}]
commit_message:
Add apiclient.exceptions hierarchy

The new apiclient.exceptions hierarchy is more comprehensive
and it covers almost all HTTP error status codes. These
exceptions can be used in novaclient, keystoneclient,
glanceclient, and other client projects thus providing a
single inteface.

Users can have benefit from OpenStack clients raising exceptions
of known classes while now every client has its own classes making
difficult to catch, e.g., NotFound for every client.

Change-Id: Ia7b25880e0ffca3526525a0f0e77c7e77c4f0076

commit_message:
Missing space at the end of the conditional expression

Missing space in the expression which enables the exercises on the
stable jobs.

The '==' changed to '=' in order to be more POSIX.

Change-Id: Icd43d15b9d00ed9a8fbc38a8e7217be2bd0de9d1

commit_message:
Replace auth_token middleware tests with httpretty

Httpretty will work in exactly the same way regardless of whether we use
the httplib or requests library. Convert it so we can modify the
middleware and know that our tests are still correct.

In this process we also split the tests from having V3 tests override
V2 tests, to having a base test class and V2 and V3 seperate overrides.

Change-Id: I1bfcecc6ae47a6dd5e76d4ceb8b3941e6ad1089f

Return success if the token is in the list we know about. If the request is for revoked tokens, then return the revoked list, else if a different token is provided, return 404 indicating an unknown (therefore unauthorized) token. """ if token_id in token_data.TOKEN_RESPONSES.keys(): status = 200 body = token_data.TOKEN_RESPONSES[token_id] elif token_id == "revoked": status = 200 body = SIGNED_REVOCATION_LIST else: status = 404 body = str() return status, body def fake_v2_responses(self, path): token_id = path.rsplit('/', 1)[1] return self._user_token_responses(token_id) def fake_v3_responses(self, path, **kwargs): headers = kwargs.get('headers') token_id = headers['X-Subject-Token'] return self._user_token_responses(token_id) def fake_v2_admin_token(self, path): status = 200 body = jsonutils.dumps({ 'access': { 'token': {'id': 'admin_token2', 'expires': '2022-10-03T16:58:01Z'} }, }) return status, body class FakeHTTPConnection(BaseFakeHTTPConnection): """Emulate a fake Keystone v2 server.""" def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): self.send_valid_revocation_list = True self.resp = None def request(self, method, path, **kwargs): """Fakes out several http responses. Support the following requests: - Create admin token ('POST /testadmin/v2.0/tokens') - Get versions ('GET /testadmin/') - Get v2 user token responses (see fake_v2_responses) """ FakeHTTPConnection.last_requested_url = path if method == 'POST' and path == '/testadmin/v2.0/tokens': status, body = self.fake_v2_admin_token(path) elif method == 'GET' and path == '/v2.0/certificates/signing': status = 200 body = token_data.SIGNING_CERT elif method == 'GET' and path == '/v2.0/certificates/ca': status = 200 body = token_data.SIGNING_CA else: if path == '/testadmin/': # It's a GET versions call status = 300 body = jsonutils.dumps(VERSION_LIST_v2) else: status, body = self.fake_v2_responses(path) self.resp = FakeHTTPResponse(status, body) def getresponse(self): # If self.resp is set then this is just the response to # the earlier request. If it is not set, then we expect # a stack of responses to have been pre-prepared if self.resp: return self.resp else: if len(FAKE_RESPONSE_STACK): return FAKE_RESPONSE_STACK.pop() return FakeHTTPResponse( 500, jsonutils.dumps('UNEXPECTED RESPONSE')) def close(self): pass class v3FakeHTTPConnection(FakeHTTPConnection): """Emulate a fake Keystone v3 server.""" def request(self, method, path, **kwargs): """Fakes out several http responses. Support the following requests: - Create admin token ('POST /testadmin/v2.0/tokens') - Get versions ('GET /testadmin/') - Get v2 user token responses (see fake_v2_responses) - Get v3 user token responses (see fake_v3_responses) """ v3FakeHTTPConnection.last_requested_url = path if method == 'POST' and path == '/testadmin/v2.0/tokens': status, body = self.fake_v2_admin_token(path) else: if path == '/testadmin/': # It's a GET versions call status = 300 body = jsonutils.dumps(VERSION_LIST_v3) elif path.split('/')[2] == 'v2.0': status, body = self.fake_v2_responses(path) else: status, body = self.fake_v3_responses(path, **kwargs) self.resp = FakeHTTPResponse(status, body) class RaisingHTTPConnection(FakeHTTPConnection): """An HTTPConnection that always raises.""" def request(self, method, path, **kwargs): raise AssertionError("HTTP request was called.") def __init__(self, expected_env=None): expected_env = expected_env or {} self.expected_env.update(expected_env)class v3FakeApp(object): def __init__(self, expected_env=None): expected_env = expected_env or {} # We should always get back the same v2 items self.expected_env = dict(EXPECTED_V2_DEFAULT_ENV_RESPONSE) # ...and with v3 additions, these are for the DEFAULT TOKEN self.expected_env.update(v3_default_env_additions) # And finally update for anything passed in self.expected_env.update(expected_env) def __call__(self, env, start_response): for k, v in self.expected_env.items(): assert env[k] == v, '%s != %s' % (env[k], v) resp = webob.Response() resp.body = 'SUCCESS' return resp(env, start_response) def setUp(self, expected_env=None, auth_version=None, fake_app=None, fake_http=None, token_dict=None): expected_env = expected_env or {} if token_dict: self.token_dict = token_dict else: self.token_dict = { 'uuid_token_default': token_data.UUID_TOKEN_DEFAULT, 'uuid_token_unscoped': token_data.UUID_TOKEN_UNSCOPED, 'signed_token_scoped': token_data.SIGNED_TOKEN_SCOPED, 'signed_token_scoped_expired': token_data.SIGNED_TOKEN_SCOPED_EXPIRED, 'revoked_token': token_data.REVOKED_TOKEN, 'revoked_token_hash': token_data.REVOKED_TOKEN_HASH } # Base assumes v2 for fake app and http, can be overridden for # child classes by called set_middleware() directly self.fake_app = fake_app or FakeApp self.fake_http = fake_http or FakeHTTPConnection self.set_middleware(self.fake_app, self.fake_http, expected_env, self.conf) # self.middleware.verify_signed_token will call # _ensure_subprocess, but we need # cms.subprocess.CalledProcessError to be imported first. # Explicitly call _ensure_subprocess to make sure the import # happens before we need it regardless of test order. cms._ensure_subprocess() signed_list = 'SIGNED_REVOCATION_LIST' valid_signed_list = 'VALID_SIGNED_REVOCATION_LIST' globals()[signed_list] = globals()[valid_signed_list] def set_fake_http(self, http_handler): """Configure the http handler for the auth_token middleware. Allows tests to override the default handler on specific tests, e.g. to use v2 for those parts of auth_token that still use v2 tokens while running the v3 test class, i.e. getting an admin token or revocation list. """ self.middleware.http_client_class = http_handler def set_middleware(self, fake_app=None, fake_http=None, expected_env=None, conf=None): conf = conf or self.conf if fake_http: conf['http_handler'] = fake_http fake_app = fake_app or self.fake_app self.middleware = auth_token.AuthProtocol(fake_app(expected_env), conf) try: os.remove(self.middleware.revoked_file_name) except OSError: passclass StackResponseAuthTokenMiddlewareTest(BaseAuthTokenMiddlewareTest): """Auth Token middleware test setup that allows the tests to define a stack of responses to HTTP requests in the test and get those responses back in sequence for testing. Example:: resp1 = FakeHTTPResponse(401, jsonutils.dumps('')) resp2 = FakeHTTPResponse(200, jsonutils.dumps({ 'access': { 'token': {'id': 'admin_token2'}, }, }) FAKE_RESPONSE_STACK.append(resp1) FAKE_RESPONSE_STACK.append(resp2) ... do your testing code here ... """ def setUp(self): super(StackResponseAuthTokenMiddlewareTest, self).setUp() def test_fetch_revocation_list_with_expire(self): # first response to revocation list should return 401 Unauthorized # to pretend to be an expired token resp1 = FakeHTTPResponse(200, jsonutils.dumps({ 'access': { 'token': {'id': 'admin_token2'}, }, })) resp2 = FakeHTTPResponse(401, jsonutils.dumps('')) resp3 = FakeHTTPResponse(200, jsonutils.dumps({ 'access': { 'token': {'id': 'admin_token2'}, }, })) resp4 = FakeHTTPResponse(200, SIGNED_REVOCATION_LIST) # first get_admin_token() call FAKE_RESPONSE_STACK.append(resp1) # request revocation list, get "unauthorized" due to simulated expired # token FAKE_RESPONSE_STACK.append(resp2) # request a new admin_token FAKE_RESPONSE_STACK.append(resp3) # commit_message:
Object API commands using our REST API layer

* Add object-store API to ClientManager
* Add object-store client
* Add Object API library in openstackclient.object.v1.lib
* Add Object API {container,object} list commands
* Add library tests
* Add command tests

This should complete the Object v1 container and object list commands

Change-Id: Ib1770d45efa8871959826b85faafa1e0bcef0a03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/42/43242/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: openstack.object_store.v1 = object_list = openstackclient.object.v1.object:ListObject

commit_message:
Delete and launch devices on the topology view

This feature enables to delete and launch a instance or router on the network
topology view. So you can do basic actions on this view.
Also it enables to change view small or normal. You can see more networks and
devices in the small view.

implements bp editable-network-topology-view

fixes bug #1215683

Change-Id: Ie65d50d2a99f72696c8f10223f8430ad5f90b144

commit_message:
Make resource_tracker record host_ip

Now that the host_ip, for affinity_filters, is coming from the DB and
the host_ip is virt driver independent so make the resource_tracker add
it.

part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler

Change-Id: I498578191b0af97cb91ca0d81b7ad1eeaf8fd995
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/42237/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: resources['host_ip'] = CONF.my_ip

commit_message:
Add "Action in progress" error for multi-engine

Raises an "Action in progress" error if an action is in progress when
another action is issued.  The engine confirms the "in progress" status
by sending an RPC to the engine doing the work.  If the stack's status
is "in progress", but no response is received, the other engine is
assumed to have died and the action will proceed as usual.

Blueprint multiple-engines

Change-Id: I9f03a2281e5dea04e45fec61fbdb1120f0a32ef0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/73/43173/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osfrom heat.openstack.common.rpc import proxy from heat.openstack.common.rpc.common import Timeout def _raise_if_stack_in_progress(self, cnxt, stack): if stack.status == parser.Stack.IN_PROGRESS: try: topic = "heat-stack-" + stack.id rpc = proxy.RpcProxy(topic, "1.0") msg = rpc.make_msg("listening") listening = rpc.call(cnxt, msg, topic=topic, timeout=2) if listening: raise exception.ActionInProgress(stack_name=stack.name, action=stack.action) except Timeout: logger.debug('No engine claimed in-progress stack %s. ' 'Continuing with action.' % stack.name) logger.debug('Creating stack in PID %s' % os.getpid()) logger.debug('Updating stack in PID %s' % os.getpid()) self._raise_if_stack_in_progress(cnxt, db_stack) logger.debug('Deleting stack in PID %s' % os.getpid()) self._raise_if_stack_in_progress(cnxt, st) self._raise_if_stack_in_progress(cnxt, s) self._raise_if_stack_in_progress(cnxt, s)

commit_message:
Cleanup sections about Multiple Compute Nodes

common/section_multiple-compute-nodes.xml was not used everywhere.
It was introduced with change I0a7fb144241be7acf7c9063e5290220b5d7b7192
that moved content to the Config Guide, thus include it from there.

openstack-install/configuring-multiple-compute-nodes.xml is a duplicate
of common/section_multiple-compute-nodes.xml which was unused as well
and thus removed.

Change-Id: I4d4158ad033d5dd97d17f4f7f3efd0be0ca6801d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/11/44311/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <section xml:id="configuring-multiple-compute-nodes" xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0"> <title>Configuring Multiple Compute Nodes</title> <para>If your goal is to split your VM load across more than one server, you can connect an additional <systemitem class="service">nova-compute</systemitem> node to a cloud controller node. This configuring can be reproduced on multiple compute servers to start building a true multi-node OpenStack Compute cluster.</para> <para>To build out and scale the Compute platform, you spread out services amongst many servers. While there are additional ways to accomplish the build-out, this section describes adding compute nodes, and the service we are scaling out is called <systemitem class="service">nova-compute</systemitem>.</para> <para>For a multi-node install you only make changes to <filename>nova.conf</filename> and copy it to additional compute nodes. Ensure each <filename>nova.conf</filename> file points to the correct IP addresses for the respective services. Customize the <filename>nova.conf</filename> example below to match your environment. The <literal>CC_ADDR</literal> is the Cloud Controller IP Address.</para> <programlisting> dhcpbridge_flagfile=/etc/nova/nova.conf dhcpbridge=/usr/bin/nova-dhcpbridge flat_network_bridge=br100 logdir=/var/log/nova state_path=/var/lib/nova verbose sql_connection=mysql://root:nova@CC_ADDR/nova s3_host=CC_ADDR rabbit_host=CC_ADDR ec2_api=CC_ADDR ec2_url=http://CC_ADDR:8773/services/Cloud network_manager=nova.network.manager.FlatManager fixed_range= network/CIDR network_size=number of addresses </programlisting> <para>By default, Nova sets the bridge device based on the setting in <literal>--flat_network_bridge</literal>. Now you can edit <filename>/etc/network/interfaces</filename> with the following template, updated with your IP information. </para> <programlisting> # The loopback network interface auto lo iface lo inet loopback # The primary network interface auto br100 iface br100 inet static bridge_ports eth0 bridge_stp off bridge_maxwait 0 bridge_fd 0 address xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx netmask xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx network xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx broadcast xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx gateway xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx # dns-* options are implemented by the resolvconf package, if installed dns-nameservers xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx </programlisting> <para>Restart networking:</para> <literallayout class="monospaced">/etc/init.d/networking restart</literallayout> <para>With <filename>nova.conf</filename> updated and networking set, configuration is nearly complete. First, bounce the relevant services to take the latest updates:</para> <literallayout class="monospaced">restart libvirt-bin; service nova-compute restart</literallayout> <para>To avoid issues with KVM and permissions with Nova, run the following commands to ensure we have VM's that are running optimally:</para> <literallayout class="monospaced"> chgrp kvm /dev/kvm chmod g+rwx /dev/kvm </literallayout> <para>If you want to use the 12.04 Ubuntu Enterprise Cloud images that are readily available at http://uec-images.ubuntu.com/releases/12.04/release/, you may run into delays with booting. Any server that does not have <systemitem class="service">nova-api</systemitem> running on it needs this iptables entry so that UEC images can get metadata info. On compute nodes, configure the iptables with this next step:</para> <literallayout class="monospaced">iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -d 169.254.169.254/32 -p tcp -m tcp --dport 80 -j DNAT --to-destination $NOVA_API_IP:8775</literallayout> <para>Lastly, confirm that your compute node is talking to your cloud controller. From the cloud controller, run this database query:</para> <literallayout class="monospaced">mysql -u$MYSQL_USER -p$MYSQL_PASS nova -e 'select * from services;'</literallayout> <para>In return, you should see something similar to this:</para> <programlisting> +---------------------+---------------------+------------+---------+----+----------+----------------+-----------+--------------+----------+-------------------+ | created_at | updated_at | deleted_at | deleted | id | host | binary | topic | report_count | disabled | availability_zone | +---------------------+---------------------+------------+---------+----+----------+----------------+-----------+--------------+----------+-------------------+ | 2011-01-28 22:52:46 | 2011-02-03 06:55:48 | NULL | 0 | 1 | osdemo02 | nova-network | network | 46064 | 0 | nova | | 2011-01-28 22:52:48 | 2011-02-03 06:55:57 | NULL | 0 | 2 | osdemo02 | nova-compute | compute | 46056 | 0 | nova | | 2011-01-28 22:52:52 | 2011-02-03 06:55:50 | NULL | 0 | 3 | osdemo02 | nova-scheduler | scheduler | 46065 | 0 | nova | | 2011-01-29 23:49:29 | 2011-02-03 06:54:26 | NULL | 0 | 4 | osdemo01 | nova-compute | compute | 37050 | 0 | nova | | 2011-01-30 23:42:24 | 2011-02-03 06:55:44 | NULL | 0 | 9 | osdemo04 | nova-compute | compute | 28484 | 0 | nova | | 2011-01-30 21:27:28 | 2011-02-03 06:54:23 | NULL | 0 | 8 | osdemo05 | nova-compute | compute | 29284 | 0 | nova | +---------------------+---------------------+------------+---------+----+----------+----------------+-----------+--------------+----------+-------------------+ </programlisting> <para>You can see that <literal>osdemo0{1,2,4,5}</literal> are all running <systemitem class="service">nova-compute</systemitem>. When you start spinning up instances, they will allocate on any node that is running <systemitem class="service">nova-compute</systemitem> from this list.</para> </section>

subject: Implement caching for Tokens and Token Validation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-21 22:10:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/b1e7b6fd9176afacd43ba42a7ca614e205b7cd3a', 'message': 'Implement caching for Tokens

Based upon the keystone caching (using dogpile.cache) implementation
token caching is implemented in this patchset.

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implemntation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:
    * token_api.get_token,
    * token_api.list_revoked_tokens
    * token_provider_api.validate_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v3_token

Calls to token_api.delete_token and token_api.delete_tokens will
properly invalidate the cache for the tokens being acted upon, as
well as invalidating the cache for the revoked_tokens_list.

DocImpact

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2013-08-25 04:26:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/a4cee20a1a376a9d84b74e0ecf67af2c6858795b', 'message': 'Implement caching for Tokens and Token Validation

Based upon the keystone caching (using dogpile.cache) implementation
token caching is implemented in this patchset.

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implemntation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:
    * token_api.get_token,
    * token_api.list_revoked_tokens
    * token_provider_api.validate_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_token

Calls to token_api.delete_token and token_api.delete_tokens will
properly invalidate the cache for the tokens being acted upon, as
well as invalidating the cache for the revoked_tokens_list and the
validate/check token calls.

Token caching is configurable independantly of the revocation_list
caching.

DocImpact

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implemntation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:

For cache consistency, all token_ids are transformed into the short

have access to the full ID (PKI Tokens), and some methods would not.
Cache invalidation is inconsistent without token_id normalization.

commit_message:
Implement caching for Tokens and Token Validation

Based upon the keystone caching (using dogpile.cache) implementation
token caching is implemented in this patchset.

This patchset inclues basic Token caching as the first implementation
of this caching layer.  The following methods are cached:
    * token_api.get_token,
    * token_api.list_revoked_tokens
    * token_provider_api.validate_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v3_token
    * token_provider_api.check_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_v2_token
    * token_provider_api.validate_token

Calls to token_api.delete_token and token_api.delete_tokens will
properly invalidate the cache for the tokens being acted upon, as
well as invalidating the cache for the revoked_tokens_list and the
validate/check token calls.

Token caching is configurable independantly of the revocation_list
caching.

Lifted expiration checks from the token drivers to the token manager.
This ensures that cached tokens will still raise TokenNotFound when
expired.

For cache consistency, all token_ids are transformed into the short
token hash at the provider and token_driver level. Some methods would
have access to the full ID (PKI Tokens), and some methods would not.
Cache invalidation is inconsistent without token_id normalization.

DocImpact

partial-blueprint: caching-layer-for-driver-calls
Change-Id: Ifada0db0043fede504a091670ccc521196c2f19c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/95/43195/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.common import cacheSHOULD_CACHE = cache.should_cache_fn('token')@dependency.requires('token_provider_api') @cache.on_arguments(should_cache_fn=SHOULD_CACHE, expiration_time=CONF.token.cache_ttl) self.driver.delete_token(self._unique_id(token_id)) self._invalidate_individual_token_cache(token_id) self.invalidate_revocation_list() def delete_tokens(self, user_id, tenant_id=None, trust_id=None, consumer_id=None): token_list = self.driver.list_tokens(user_id, tenant_id, trust_id, consumer_id) self.driver.delete_tokens(user_id, tenant_id, trust_id, consumer_id) for token_id in token_list: self._invalidate_individual_token_cache(token_id) self.invalidate_revocation_list() @cache.on_arguments(should_cache_fn=SHOULD_CACHE) def list_revoked_tokens(self): return self.driver.list_revoked_tokens() def _invalidate_individual_token_cache(self, token_id): """Invalidate the token driver cache for a given token_id.""" # NOTE(morganfainberg): invalidate takes the exact same arguments as # the normal method, this means we need to pass "self" in (which gets # stripped off). self.get_token.invalidate(self, token_id) self.token_provider_api.invalidate_individual_token_cache(token_id) def invalidate_revocation_list(self): # NOTE(morganfainberg): we should always be keeping the revoked tokens # list in memory, calling refresh in this case instead of ensures a # cache hit when list_revoked_tokens is called again. This is an # exception to the rule. Note that ``self`` needs to be passed to # refresh() because of the way the invalidation/refresh methods work on # determining cache-keys. self.list_revoked_tokens.refresh(self)
deleted_lines: return self.driver.delete_token(self._unique_id(token_id))

commit_message:
Add support for parsing jsonfied heat error

Keep the legacy method for the cases that user may use
an old version of heat.

Fixes bug #1207624
Change-Id: I3346d7a6f8f51746ee5455720f093cd785623634
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/78/38578/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
try: error = json.loads(str(e)) return error['error'].get('message', 'Generic Error') except Exception: # NOTE(jianingy): fallback to legacy message parsing approach # either if error message isn't a json nor the json isn't in # valid format. validation_patterns = [ "Remote error: \w* {'Error': '(.*?)'}", 'Remote error: \w* (.*?) \[', '400 Bad Request

The server could not comply with the request ' 'since it is either malformed or otherwise incorrect.

 (.*)', '(ParserError: .*)' ] for pattern in validation_patterns: match = re.search(pattern, str(e)) if match: return match.group(1)

subject: Unimplemented suspend/resume should not change vm state
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-07-23 07:38:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/567ca9b28ad36ba5eb3fa2f200f68c6adaa16367', 'message': "Unimplemented suspend should not change vm state on PowerVM

The instance of PowerVM does not support suspend, but
after suspend the instance, the state change to SUSPENDED,
it's needed to fix this.

Change-Id: I8150a898fee91bbe66f1502638baca8050e2dd6d
Fixes: bug #1203986
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-08-06 07:07:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/837eef76a5a9d3c15121bc5534b0fa90fbae85a6', 'message': "Unimplemented suspend/resume should not change vm state on PowerVM

The instance of PowerVM does not support suspend/resume, but
after suspend/resume the instance, the state change to
SUSPENDED/ACTIVE.
It's needed to keep the state always in Active and show
the explicit notification of NotImplement on compute.log
when suspend and resume actions were excuted.

Fixes: bug #1203986

after suspend/resume the instance, the state change to
SUSPENDED/ACTIVE.
It's needed to keep the state always in Active and show
the explicit notification of NotImplement on compute.log
when suspend and resume actions were executed.
Just change compute manager in this review since review
39107 is doing the other part patch to powervm driver
and powervm test_powervm.

Change-Id: I8150a898fee91bbe66f1502638baca8050e2dd6d
Fixes: bug #1203986
"}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2013-08-19 08:59:40.000000000', 'files': ['nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/tests/compute/test_compute.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/02ae8a091dc611bc90a7e975c83f53e5fa579fdc', 'message': "Unimplemented suspend/resume should not change vm state

When the underlying virt driver does not implement the suspend/resume API
and raises a NotImplementedError, the compute manager will error out and
change the instance's vm_state to ERROR. With this change, the compute
manager will handle the NotImplementedError and keep the instance
vm_state as it was before the error.

Change-Id: I8150a898fee91bbe66f1502638baca8050e2dd6d

commit_message:
Unimplemented suspend/resume should not change vm state

When the underlying virt driver does not implement the suspend/resume API
and raises a NotImplementedError, the compute manager will error out and
change the instance's vm_state to ERROR. With this change, the compute
manager will handle the NotImplementedError and keep the instance
vm_state as it was before the error.

Change-Id: I8150a898fee91bbe66f1502638baca8050e2dd6d
Fixes: bug #1203986

commit_message:
Fix the Domain Context for Users panel

Add display of Domain ID and Domain Name in the Create and Update
Users page to give user a hint where the User will be created.
For Keystone V2, the two fields will be hidden.

When the Domain Context is set, the User will be created in that
Domain Context. Otherwise, the User will be created in the Domain
of the logon user.

On users creation, the listing of available projects will be based
on the Domain where it will be created.

Fixes bug 1215697

Change-Id: I780d11289ab73804d0d26ad71a07ece6b2da74ad

commit_message:
Defer computation of available methods until needed.

In practice this data is almost only ever needed if we're throwing an
HTTPMethodNotAllowed error, so we can avoid computing on every single
request to the proxy server.

Change-Id: I2abafa3aeb63ca6974dfcf6f31c864c049681f37
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/58/44458/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._allowed_methods = None @property def allowed_methods(self): if self._allowed_methods is None: self._allowed_methods = set() all_methods = inspect.getmembers(self, predicate=inspect.ismethod) for name, m in all_methods: if getattr(m, 'publicly_accessible', False): self._allowed_methods.add(name) return self._allowed_methods
deleted_lines: self.allowed_methods = set() all_methods = inspect.getmembers(self, predicate=inspect.ismethod) for name, m in all_methods: if getattr(m, 'publicly_accessible', False): self.allowed_methods.add(name)

commit_message:
Disable compute fanout to scheduler

Now that nothing is using publish_service_capabilities it can be
disabled, but not removed in order to not break compute rpcapi backwards
compatibility.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler.

Change-Id: I80c49c46138fd6ee89cb08ffbbced72ada4de72e

commit_message:
Make image_props_filter use information from DB not RPC

Make image_props_filter directly use the data from host_state and not
the data from capabilities that is currently broadcast from the
scheduler over RPC, as this will be removed since it doesn't scale.

Once all capabilities usage in scheduler filters is
removed the capabilities RPC broadcast can be removed.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler.

Change-Id: I5e6bcec517edbf606903c3e98f3c63f7ba370bcf

commit_message:
Make compute_capabilities_filter use information from DB not RPC

Make compute_capabilities_filter directly use the data in host_state and
not the data capabilities data that is currently broadcast from the
schedulers over RPC, as this will be removed since it doesn't scale.

The filter name, compute_capabilities_filter, is kept the same to keep
backwards compatibility.

This is a second attempt at this patch the first one broke the ability
to filter an arbitrary key value pairs, this time that is supported via
host_state.stats, along with tests to confirm

Once all the capabilities usage in scheduler filters is removed, the
capabilities RPC broadcast can be removed.

Part of bp no-compute-fanout-to-scheduler.

Change-Id: I0b9b05a25a8c1841093913c4a2fb19b48aff2ae1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/28/43928/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.openstack.common import jsonutils self.hypervisor_type = None self.hypervisor_version = None self.hypervisor_hostname = None self.cpu_info = None self.supported_instances = None # All virt drivers report host_ip self.hypervisor_type = compute.get('hypervisor_type') self.hypervisor_version = compute.get('hypervisor_version') self.hypervisor_hostname = compute.get('hypervisor_hostname') self.cpu_info = compute.get('cpu_info') if compute.get('supported_instances'): self.supported_instances = jsonutils.loads( compute.get('supported_instances')) # Don't store stats directly in host_state to make sure these don't # overwrite any values, or get overwritten themselves. Store in self so # filters can schedule with them. self.stats = self._statmap(compute.get('stats', [])) self.num_instances = int(self.stats.get('num_instances', 0)) project_id_keys = [k for k in self.stats.keys() if self.num_instances_by_project[project_id] = int(self.stats[key]) vm_state_keys = [k for k in self.stats.keys() if k.startswith("num_vm_")] self.vm_states[vm_state] = int(self.stats[key]) task_state_keys = [k for k in self.stats.keys() if self.task_states[task_state] = int(self.stats[key]) os_keys = [k for k in self.stats.keys() if k.startswith("num_os_type_")] self.num_instances_by_os_type[os] = int(self.stats[key]) self.num_io_ops = int(self.stats.get('io_workload', 0))
deleted_lines: stats = compute.get('stats', []) statmap = self._statmap(stats) self.num_instances = int(statmap.get('num_instances', 0)) project_id_keys = [k for k in statmap.keys() if self.num_instances_by_project[project_id] = int(statmap[key]) vm_state_keys = [k for k in statmap.keys() if k.startswith("num_vm_")] self.vm_states[vm_state] = int(statmap[key]) task_state_keys = [k for k in statmap.keys() if self.task_states[task_state] = int(statmap[key]) os_keys = [k for k in statmap.keys() if k.startswith("num_os_type_")] self.num_instances_by_os_type[os] = int(statmap[key]) self.num_io_ops = int(statmap.get('io_workload', 0))

commit_message:
Added Hive configuration, new nodeprocess - hiveserver

* Configuration hive-site.xml for Derby DB
* Added hive-default.xml
* Creating hive warehouse dir in HDFS
* Plugin validation exceptions

Implements blueprint edp-vanilla-plugin-hive-pig

Change-Id: I68b4f1307b8ff565d60d26c415eed1f553b8d5eb

commit_message:
Get rid of pycrypto dep

* ssh keys are generated with ssh-keygen now;
* most of the code is ported from nova.

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-06-07 19:26:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/bdc5edfc3d1b1661ae91866a2bdd39d2fad20a67', 'message': 'Bug 1178375

This is for the Qpid rpc implementation - impl_qpid.py

Major restructuring of the Qpid exchange topology to solve leaky
exchange issue.

This also gets away from creating exchanges for all sort of htings.

The emphasis now is on AMQP 1.0 type addressing. There is no need for lots
of exchanges.

This will also help simplify any federation that may be needed for federation.
The topology is now all under the amq.topic excahnge.

amq.topic/topic/sometopicHLQ.sometopicLLQ.etc.
amq.topic/direct/somedirectaddress
amq.topic/fanout/somefanoutname

Change-Id: I09b8317c0d8a298237beeb3105f2b90cb13933d8
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2013-08-28 17:22:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/8a328a57fe86440b4b9eb97942f504cdb8831986', 'message': "Support a new qpid topology

There has been a bug open for a while pointing out that the way we
create fanout exchanges with qpid results in leaking exchanges since
qpid doesn't support auto-deleting exchanges.  This was somewhat
mitigated by change to use a single reply queue.  This meant we created
far fewer direct exchanges, but the problem persists anyway.

A Qpid expert, William Henry, originally proposed a change to address
this issue.  Unfortunately, it wasn't backwards compatible with existing
installations.  This patch takes the same approach, but makes it
optional and off by default.  This will allow a migration period.

As a really nice side effect, the Qpid experts have told us that this
change will also allow us to use Qpid broker federation to provide HA.

Closes-bug: #1178375
Co-authored-by: William Henry <whenry@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I09b8317c0d8a298237beeb3105f2b90cb13933d8
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2013-08-28 17:34:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/d6fed4860ad7ea2036f003f6adb6d2bbbec057ec', 'message': "Support a new qpid topology

There has been a bug open for a while pointing out that the way we
create direct exchanges with qpid results in leaking exchanges since
qpid doesn't support auto-deleting exchanges.  This was somewhat
mitigated by change to use a single reply queue.  This meant we created
far fewer direct exchanges, but the problem persists anyway.

A Qpid expert, William Henry, originally proposed a change to address
this issue.  Unfortunately, it wasn't backwards compatible with existing

optional and off by default.  This will allow a migration period.

commit_message:
Support a new qpid topology

There has been a bug open for a while pointing out that the way we
create direct exchanges with qpid results in leaking exchanges since
qpid doesn't support auto-deleting exchanges.  This was somewhat
mitigated by change to use a single reply queue.  This meant we created
far fewer direct exchanges, but the problem persists anyway.

A Qpid expert, William Henry, originally proposed a change to address
this issue.  Unfortunately, it wasn't backwards compatible with existing
installations.  This patch takes the same approach, but makes it
optional and off by default.  This will allow a migration period.

As a really nice side effect, the Qpid experts have told us that this
change will also allow us to use Qpid broker federation to provide HA.

DocImpact
Closes-bug: #1178375
Co-authored-by: William Henry <whenry@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I09b8317c0d8a298237beeb3105f2b90cb13933d8

commit_message:
Introduces Basic Report and Model

Introduces the classes for basic reports and the base data model
class to hold data for the report.  A basic report is composed of
sections, each of which has a generator (which produces the model)
and a view (which converts the model into a given representation).
Models may have an associated view, as well, to allow for sub-models
to have specific views attached to them.  This is the first part
of the Guru Meditation Report Framework.

Change-Id: Ic3ad1fd595da8742b5e7d4349a23132fc560f292
Implements: bp guru-meditation-report
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/15/36315/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2011 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from openstack.common.report import report from openstack.common.report.models import base as base_model from tests import utils class BasicView(object): def __call__(self, model): res = "" for k,v in model.items(): res += str(k) + ": " + str(v) + ";" return res def basic_generator(): return base_model.ReportModel(data={'string': 'value', 'int': 1}) class TestBasicReport(utils.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestBasicReport, self).setUp() self.report = report.BasicReport() def test_add_section(self): self.report.add_section(BasicView(), basic_generator) self.assertEqual(len(self.report.sections), 1) def test_append_section(self): self.report.add_section(BasicView(), lambda: {'a': 1}) self.report.add_section(BasicView(), basic_generator) self.assertEqual(len(self.report.sections), 2) self.assertEqual(self.report.sections[1].generator, basic_generator) def test_insert_section(self): self.report.add_section(BasicView(), lambda: {'a': 1}) self.report.add_section(BasicView(), basic_generator, 0) self.assertEqual(len(self.report.sections), 2) self.assertEqual(self.report.sections[0].generator, basic_generator) def test_basic_render(self): self.report.add_section(BasicView(), basic_generator) self.assertEquals(self.report.run(), "int: 1;string: value;") def test_submodel_attached_view(self): class TmpView(object): def __call__(self, model): return '{len: ' + str(len(model.c)) + '}' def generate_model_with_submodel(): base_m = basic_generator() base_m['submodel'] = base_model.ReportModel(data={'c': [1,2,3]}, attached_view=TmpView()) return base_m self.report.add_section(BasicView(), generate_model_with_submodel) self.assertEqual(self.report.run(), 'int: 1;string: value;submodel: {len: 3};')

commit_message:
Move Heat to a single heat.conf

the old config files that are no longer needed (but still supported):
heat-engine.conf, heat-api.conf, heat-api-cfn.conf, heat-api-cw.conf

Change-Id: I7ba0566325539bf7215bcb606843a90b5e3e4a98
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/99/44199/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix NTP and DNS Sections

DNS section was nested inside the NTP section, which resulted in
incorrect formatting

Change-Id: I123a9a0d001318388475b9383b4057dd35904668
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/42/44342/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DNS OpenStack does not currently provide DNS services, aside from the dnsmasq daemon which resides on nova-network hosts. You could consider providing a dynamic DNS service to allow instances to update a DNS entry with new IP addresses. You can also consider making a generic forward and reverse DNS mapping for instance's IP addresses, such as vm-203-0-113-123.example.com.
deleted_lines: DNS OpenStack does not currently provide DNS services, aside from the dnsmasq daemon which resides on nova-network hosts. You could consider providing a dynamic DNS service to allow instances to update a DNS entry with new IP addresses. You can also consider making a generic forward and reverse DNS mapping for instance's IP addresses, such as vm-203-0-113-123.example.com.

commit_message:
OAuth authorizing user should propose roles to delegate

Currently in the oauth1 extension the consumer specifies roles
instead of delegator. This is a design fault that should be fixed
by having the authorizing user provide a set of roles (ids)
during the authorize request token phase.

fixes bug: #1216408

Change-Id: I08e803c7e046d4a2436c08535e2344ee654de889

commit_message:
Removed instance reset_password from python-troveclient

The reset_password operation no longer exists and needs to be removed
from python-troveclient.

Change-Id: Ic162ef6deb86716fa12fa5541699f602c246563e
Fixes: bug 1199507
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-troveclient refs/changes/96/42996/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def reset_password(self, instance_id): """ Resets the database instance root password. :param instance_id: The :class:`Instance` (or its ID) to share onto. """ body = {'reset-password': {}} return self._action(instance_id, body)
